msgSnippet: So said  Mike Colbert   on  12/15/2002 ... You didn t ask me, but I don t find it particularly rude. I think the joke about Canadians
messageBody:
So said Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@...> on 12/15/2002
--------------------

>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Bill de hÓra <dehora@e...> wrote:
>> To me Mike, you're coming across as rude.
>
>I'm curious, do you find this rude?
>http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/6415

You didn't ask me, but I don't find it particularly rude. I think the
joke about Canadians being unusually polite might put some people off,
but being Canadian, I understand.

>To me, it smacks of self-righteousness and shameless self-promotion.

You know what, that's not so bad. When I do good work that I think
helps people, I promote it. If they find it good, they also promote it.
If they find it bad, they tell me and I stop promoting it.

I wrote "JUnit: A Starter Guide" in response to two solid weeks of
complaining on this list about how crappy the JUnit documentation is.
About four people in a row said they wanted a tutorial and I wrote one,
then found some other good ones on the web. Mike Clark put together a
FAQ to go along side his excellent tutorial. Among us all, I think we
have the tutorial angle covered. Several thousand people have read that
document and I haven't seen a single complaint on this list since that
time. That was about a year ago.

Let me ask you, am I wrong to be proud of that and to refer people to
it if they ask for a tutorial?

>I didn't come here to have some guy and his buddy disparage the ideas
>that I offer without offering anything in exchange other than, "This
>is how it is. Buy my book!"

See, this is just sad. First, I'm not "his buddy". Dave and I have
exchanged the odd e-mail, but we hardly know each other. We respect
each other's work (at least I hope), but that's all. I trust that Dave
will tackle your problem in an upcoming Coad letter. I thought it was
rude of you to insist he get off his ass and answer your question right
now. That was how I saw your comment. Just because the man didn't want
to type a long answer right that second doesn't mean that he didn't
have a good answer and it doesn't mean that he wasn't going to share
his answer. And OF COURSE if he has written the answer in a book, I
don't blame him for wanting you to buy the book, rather than get his
advice free. Be aware that we could be charging hundreds of dollars per
day for our advice. We are volunteers here.

>I think if a person jumps into a discussion and says, "Your approach
>sucks. Buy my book!" they should at least explain why. That might
>actually be helpful to others.

I honestly didn't see "Your approach sucks". I hope that my other reply
made it clearer what I think Dave was getting at: most people
misunderstand (as I did for two years) why the class TestCase is meant
to embody a test fixture. The fact that it's named TestCase is a source
of confusion. Kent admitted that himself!

>> Yet, I haven't
>> seen any explanation as to what is inferior in your approach -
>> asserting it's inferior does not make it so.
>
>I couldn't agree more.

If I say "you should brush your teeth", do you attack me? The bottom
line is that you *should* brush your teeth, assuming that you want good
dental health and your teeth to last a long time. If you don't care
about dental health, or if your teeth are magical and stay clean all on
their own, or if not brushing your teeth hasn't affected your life to
this point, then certainly, continue not brushing your teeth.

HOWEVER, if later on your teeth all fall out and you don't like what
that does to you, then you make look back on my advice and say, "You
know, perhaps I should have brushed my teeth."

So you can take it as you like. Either assume that we're Just Trying To
Help or assume that we're out to disparage you. Your choice. If you
choose to believe that we're out to disparage you, then please
understand when we say that we know better than you know what our
intentions are.

>> I also found the waving
>> of the moderator stick distasteful; it's far too early for that.
>>
>> A suggestion - stop posting for 24 hours on this thread, then come
>> back to it.
>>
>> Bill de hÓra
>
>Whoops, too late for that! Heheh.
>
>For the record, I never said I disagreed with what Dave and J. B. are
>advocating. I never said I didn't like them personally, either.
>It's the delivery of their message I find curious. It seems more
>geared toward self-interest than equitable exchange or mutual benefit.

I would love for you to show me where, in my reply, you felt that my
advice was delivered with self-interest as opposed to YOUR benefit,
nevermind MUTUAL benefit. At least one of us will be able to learn from
that exercise, and probably both.

I mean messages 6421, 6435 and 6442 up until the point that I objected
to what I perceived as your rudeness.
